page.title: 09ANCIENT HISTORY IN NETHERTON
page.content: Originally known as Faccombe Netherton, with Faccombe Up Street being the hamlet on the hill. In the 14th and 15th centuries the Manor was split and Faccombe Up Street became the more important of the two villages. The word Faccombe was dropped from Netherton. From 1967 to 1980 excavations were carried out on the site of the 14th century Manor, revealing approximately 35 households. With a standard of 5 to 6 people per home, the population was about 200. Subsequent digging uncovered remains from Saxon times. The church was allowed to fall into disrepair and the parishioners at Netherton began to worship at the new church in Faccombe in the late 19th century. The original churchyard remains at Netherton, the well kept lychgate is dated 1896.
